title: Phishing (fake login pages and ‘verify your details’)
summary: Phishing tricks you into giving away passwords, codes, or personal info by pretending to be a trusted organisation.
how_it_works: A scam message claims there’s a security issue, refund, or required update.
It pushes you to click a link or open an attachment.
The link leads to a fake login page that captures your username/password (and sometimes 2FA codes).
warning_signs: Link/attachment asks you to log in with your username and password.
Generic greeting, spelling mistakes, or strange sender address.
Website address doesn’t match the real organisation.
example_hooks: “You have an unclaimed rebate — log in to claim.”
what_to_do: Do not click links/attachments if you’re unsure.
Go to the real site by typing the address yourself or using the official app.
Change passwords if you entered them, and enable 2FA where possible.

quick_quiz.q: What’s the safest way to get to the real website?
choices: Click the link in the message
Type the website address yourself or use the official app
Reply and ask them for another link
quick_quiz.explain: Scam messages often include links to fake sites. Typing the address yourself (or using the official app) reduces that risk.

quick_quiz.q: A message says you must act 'within 24 hours' or you'll lose access. What should you do first?
choices: Stop and verify using official contact details you find yourself
Forward it to friends to ask
quick_quiz.explain: Urgency is a classic pressure tactic. Verify using trusted contact details.
